channel.title: JavaScript Weekly
channel.description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects

item.title: ã€TC39: No to records and tuples, yes to enumsã€‘TC39ï¼šå¦è®°å½•å’Œå…ƒç´ ï¼Œæ˜¯çš„
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹732 â€” April 18, 2025

Read on the Web

ğŸ¥š A Good Friday, if you celebrate Easter at all. We're taking a little break but didn't want to take the entire week off, so we have a slimline issue for you todayÂ :-) We'll be back to full service nextÂ Friday!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

The ECMAScript Records and Tuples Proposal Has Been Withdrawn â€” Several years in the making, the record and tuples proposal offered two new deeply immutable data structures to JavaScript, but at this weekâ€™s TC39 meeting, the consensus was to dropÂ it.

There have, however, been some more positive updates:

  • A proposal for introducing enums to JavaScript has advanced to stage 1. It seeks the adoption of a compatible form of TypeScript's enum declaration. Slidedeck here.

  • The Deferred re-exports proposal has advanced to stage 2. There's a slidedeck walking through the feature.

  • The Upsert and Composites proposals have beenÂ advanced.

It's worth following Rob Palmer if you want to keep up to date with TC39 goings-on as he's always sharing the latestÂ news.

Plug & Play Image Editor For Your Web App â€” Save yourself the headache of building an image editor. Import the pintura module, give it an image source, and instantly get features like cropping, rotating, resizing, and annotation. Need help? Support has you covered. Try it for freeÂ today.

Pintura sponsor

Hako: A New High-Performance Embeddable JavaScript Engine â€” A fork of PrimJS (which is, itself, built on top of QuickJS) that compiles down to WebAssembly and can act as a portable, embeddable JavaScript engine for other apps (hereâ€™s an example of using it in a GoÂ app).

Andrew Sampson

IN BRIEF:

  • Mozilla has enabled its Temporal implementation by default as of Firefox 139.

  • ğŸ“˜ Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has released Exploring TypeScript: TS 5.8 edition, a book bringing together all of his recent research into modern TypeScript development. You can buy the book but also read it all online for free in HTML form, if youÂ prefer.

  • ESLint has added support for 'bulk suppressions', a way to make adopting stricter linting rules moreÂ manageable.

  • Dan Abramov is back with JSX Over The Wire, a fantastic meditation on the evolution of passing data and behavior between servers and clients and how things could get evenÂ better.

  • ğŸ¤– Microsoft's Burke Holland â–¶ï¸ shows off VS Code's new 'agent mode' feature which really makes Copilot far more powerful and a fine alternative to dedicated AI-poweredÂ editors. I've been using it a lot thisÂ week.

  • Google has made Firebase App Hosting generally available. It offers a streamlined, fully-managed deployment process for Angular and Next.jsÂ apps.

  • Sacha Greif, the name behind the State of JavaScript survey, has just launched the first 'State of Devs' survey. ğŸ—³ï¸ You can fill it out here.

RELEASES:

  • Astro 5.7 â€“ The popular content framework gains an experimental fonts API, its sessions API is now stable, and there's support for using local SVG files asÂ components.

  • WebStorm 2025.1 â€“ JetBrains' JavaScript IDE â€“ fresh with big AI, Angular, monorepo, and Next.js enhancements.

  • tldts 7.0 â€“ URL parsing library to extract domains, subdomains, suffixes,Â etc.

  • gridstack.js 12.0 â€“ Build responsive interactive dashboardsÂ quickly.

  • Lexe â€“ Package a Node app into a single, small executable.

  • DOCX 9.4 â€“ Generate Word documents fromÂ JavaScript.

  • Redux Toolkit 2.7, Bun v1.2.10, Babylon.js 8.3, Rambda 10.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

A Flowing WebGL Gradient, Deconstructed â€” Even if you donâ€™t want to render a neat plasma-style effect on the Web, this is a wonderfully deep exploration of the math and technology behind doing so using simple GLSL code that could be easily understood by any JavaScriptÂ developer.

Alex Harri

ğŸ’¡ If you like stuff like this, this CodePen of a GLSL-based swirl effect is neatÂ too.

Advanced React in the Wild â€” A round-up of case studies showing how five different engineering teams have pushed React to the limit in production and their real-world wins in areas like performance, Core Web Vitals, caching, and more. A lot to enjoyÂ here.

Addy Osmani and Hassan Djirdeh

ğŸ“º Building Single Page Apps with SvelteKit â€“ And not only that, you can create SvelteKit apps in a single HTML file that can run without a Web server. (15Â minutes) Stanislav Khromov

ğŸ“„ How I Track My Blogâ€™s Analytics with Val Town Orestis Papadopoulos

ğŸ“„ Deploying TypeScript: Recent Advances and Possible Future Directions Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“„ Zero-Config Debugging with Deno and OpenTelemetry Casonato and Jiang (Deno)

ğŸ“„ Creating an AI Chat Experience with React and OpenAI Robin Wieruch

__
Peter Cooper, your editor

item.title: ã€Comparing Tauri and Electronã€‘æ¯”è¾ƒé™¶é‡Œå’Œç”µå­
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹731 â€” April 11, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

ğŸ¤–Â Firebase Studio: Google's New Agentic AI-Powered Development Environment â€” Buzzing from the success of Gemini 2.5 Pro for dev tasks, Googleâ€™s Firebase team gets in on the AI development action with a Cursor/v0/Lovable-a-like of its own for building apps in theÂ browser.

Google

Some Features Every JavaScript Developer Should Know in 2025 â€” A quick list post breezing through a few more modern areas of JavaScript including iterator helpers, structuredClone(), and setÂ operations.

Suren Enfiajyan

Next.js Fundamentals, v4 â€” Master Next.js with Scott Moss. Learn React Server Components, Server Actions, dynamic routing, authentication, caching, and edge functions. Create a modern React app, deploy it to Vercel, and level up yourÂ skills.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Node.js Testing Best Practices â€” A detailed guide to modern testing in Node from a group of developers who know all about it. Itâ€™s on GitHub, but essentially written like a free book covering over 50 battle-tested tips covering areas as diverse as the â€˜Testing Diamondâ€™, testing microservices, and simulating flakyÂ networks.

Goldberg, Salomon, and Gluskin

IN BRIEF:

  • There's speculation that the npm registry may have wiped all access tokens. If you're having problems, the status update recommends creating new tokens while they attempt to restoreÂ them.

  • â˜ï¸ It's been a busy week for Cloudflare! It now has an easy way to deploy Next.js apps to Cloudflare Workers, you can add a 'deploy to Workers' button to your Git repos, v1 of their Cloudflare Vite plugin has been released, and you can now deploy an entire frontend, backend, and database (supporting React Router, Astro, Vue.js, Svelte and more) in oneÂ Worker.

  • The RedwoodJS team has an update on the future of Redwood and what the 'next epoch' holds for the React-basedÂ framework.

  • p5.js 2.0 looks like it'll be with us soon â€“ its eighth beta has just landed. The release notes for beta 2 give an extensive idea of what'sÂ coming.

  • ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡´ The annual JSHeroes conference is taking place this May 29-30 in Cluj,Â Romania.

RELEASES:

  • TypeSpec 1.0-RC â€“ Microsoft's language for defining cloud service APIs andÂ shapes.

  • pnpm 10.8 â€“ The alternative, efficient packageÂ manager.

  • Prisma 6.6 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js andÂ TypeScript.

  • React Native 0.79 â€“ Faster, faster,Â faster.

  • Bun 1.2.9, Tailwind CSS 4.1, CKEditor5 45, Zod 4 Beta

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Comparing Tauri and Electron for Building Desktop Apps â€” Electron is a natural choice for building JS and HTML-powered cross-platform desktop apps but numerous alternatives have appeared like Neutralinojs and the Rust-based Tauri. This post does a good job of quickly showing how Tauri differs and why you might chooseÂ it.

Costa Alexoglou

Mastering Default Values with Nullish Coalescing (??) â€” Mattâ€™s a big fan of the ?? operator over the || approach, largely due to JavaScriptâ€™s ideas of what it considers â€˜falsyâ€™.

Matt Smith

How Clerk Integrates with a Next.js Application Using Supabase â€” Learn how Supabase + Clerk work with Next.js to increase security and reduce developmentÂ hours.

Clerk sponsor

Accelerating Large-Scale Test Migration with LLMs â€” How Airbnb completed its first large-scale, LLM-driven code migration in moving from Enzyme to React TestingÂ Library.

Charles Covey-Brandt (Airbnb)

React Reconciliation: The Hidden Engine Behind Your Components â€” React uses a reconciliation algorithm to update the DOM based on changes to the virtual DOM. Understanding how it works is essential for producing fasterÂ apps.

Christian Ekrem

Hiding Elements That Require JavaScript Without UsingÂ JavaScript â€” If youâ€™ve got non-essential features that require JavaScript and you want to hide them for users who have JavaScript disabled for whatever reason, this is a tidy old-school way to doÂ it.

Dade

ğŸ“„ Debugging JavaScript Memory Leaks in Bun Jarred Sumner

ğŸ“„ Using Chrome's (Preview) Prompt API for Data Summarization Raymond Camden

ğŸ“„ How to Easily Reproduce a Flaky Test in Playwright Nicolas Charpentier

ğŸ“„ Securing a Vue App with OpenID Connect and the BFF Pattern â€“ Thatâ€™s Backend-for-Frontend, not Best FriendsÂ Forever. Khalid Abuhakmeh

ğŸ“„ The Case for Web Components with Lit Philipp Kunz

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Next.js 15.3: Now Including Turbopack Builds â€” The popular React framework now includes alpha support for using Turbopack for much faster production builds (especially if you have lots of cores available), community support for Rspack, and new navigationÂ hooks.

The Vercel / Next.js Team

Chrono 2.8: A Natural Language Date Parser â€” Give it a string like â€œtodayâ€, â€œlast Fridayâ€, â€œ2 weeks from nowâ€, or even an entire date and time, and itâ€™ll come up with a date object toÂ suit.

Wanasit Tanakitrungruang

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, Jest, Karma, Jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

ğŸµÂ Communicate with Ableton Live via WebSockets â€” Ableton Live is a popular DAW (digital audio workstation) and this opens up a way to control it fromÂ JavaScript.

Ricardo Matias

  • ğŸ•’ Spacetime 7.9 â€“ Lightweight timezoneÂ library. Now supporting formatting times in SQL ISOÂ format.

  • ğŸ“Š Perspective 3.5 â€“ Streaming data viz and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled toÂ WASM.

  • Embla Carousel 8.6 â€“ Lightweight carousel library with fluid motion and swipeÂ precision.

  • simpleParallax.js 6.1 â€“ Add parallax effects to anyÂ image.

  • Tesseract.js 6.0.1 â€“ Pure JS OCR for 100+ languages.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Working on the frontend? ğŸš€ Frontend Focus is a weekly update â€” trusted by 75,000+ devs â€” covering the essential trends, tools and tips that matter.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of other interesting updates and useful resources from across the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • Git has turned 20 years old and GitHub's Taylor Blau caught up with Linus Torvalds to discuss the milestone and the background to the project.

  • Tired of hearing about TypeScript? Why not experiment with programming in PostScript and running games on your printer?

  • Minimal CSS-only Blurry Image Placeholders is an article showing off a very clever technique for using CSS to dynamically create blurry image placeholders prior to an image loadingÂ in.

  • Mozilla's Simon Pieters tells us that default styles for H1 elements are changing and browsers are starting to roll out changes in default styles for nested sectionÂ headings.

  • Docker has released a new extension for VS Code in a collaboration with the Microsoft Container ToolsÂ team.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

Costa Alexoglou

Charles Covey-Brandtï¼ˆAirbnbï¼‰

- Reactä½¿ç”¨å¯¹å¸ç®—æ³•æ ¹æ®è™šæ‹ŸDOMçš„æ›´æ”¹æ¥æ›´æ–°DOMã€‚äº†è§£å…¶å·¥ä½œåŸç†å¯¹äºç”Ÿäº§æ›´å¿«çš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè‡³å…³é‡è¦ã€‚

Christian Ekrem

éœ€è¦ä½¿ç”¨JavaScript ä¸éœ€è¦JavaScript çš„éšè—å…ƒç´  - å¦‚æœæ‚¨æœ‰éœ€è¦JavaScriptçš„ä¸å¿…è¦çš„åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æ‚¨æƒ³å°†å®ƒä»¬éšè—èµ·æ¥ï¼Œä»¥ä½¿ä»–ä»¬å¯¹javaScriptè¿›è¡ŒjavaScriptçš„ç”¨æˆ·éšè—ï¼Œä»»ä½•åŸå› æ˜¯å‡ºäºä»»ä½•åŸå› ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜“äºæ—§çš„æ—§å¼çš„æ—§é“è·¯ã€‚

dade

ğŸ“„ğŸ“„ğŸ“„ğŸ“„ Khalid Abuhakmeh

ğŸ“„

ğŸ“¢Â åœ¨å…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹

ä»æ›´å¹¿æ³›çš„å¼€å‘äººå‘˜æ™¯è§‚ä¸­çš„å…¶ä»–æœ‰è¶£çš„æ›´æ–°å’Œæœ‰ç”¨çš„èµ„æºè¿›è¡Œå¿«é€Ÿç»¼è¿°ï¼š

  • gitå·²20å²ï¼Œ

  • åŒå€¦äº†å¬åˆ°æ‰“å­—ç¨¿ï¼Ÿä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆä¸å°è¯•

  • Mozillaçš„Simon Pieterså‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘ä»¬ï¼Œ

item.title: ã€Bring back the fun with p5.js 2.0ã€‘ç”¨P5.JS 2.0å¸¦å›ä¹è¶£
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹733 â€” April 25, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

p5.js 2.0: The JavaScript Library for Creative Coding â€” A popular Processing-inspired creative coding library that makes it easy to create interactive, visual experiences (examples). v2.0 improves its font support, adds more ways to draw and manipulate text, adds a way to write shaders in JavaScript, and much more. p5.js 2.0: You Are Here has more details on the release and where the project is headedÂ next.

p5.js Team

ğŸ’¡ p5.js is simultaneously useful and fun. It provides a great abstraction for interactive, visual experiences and is easy to play with using its online editor. A pastime of mine is asking AI models to create demos. For example, load this p5.js sketch and hit play to see a JS logo glitch experiment OpenAI's o3 just made forÂ me.

Unbork Your Laravel App (Live) â€” Laravel is so in right now. Join us for a hands-on debugging session using a demo app, Unborked. Weâ€™ll track errors, replay sessions, trace slowdowns, and maybe even let the robots help. Bring yourÂ bugs.

Sentry sponsor

Big Updates in the React World â€” You know itâ€™s been a big week in the React world when the React Compiler hitting Release Candidate is the second most important story. In this latest React Labs post, we learn about two new features ready to try out today in react@experimental: View Transitions and the <Activity> component.

Ricky Hanlon

IN BRIEF:

  • SolidJS creator Ryan Carniato reflects on a decade running the SolidJS project, four years after hitting v1.0.

  • Back in March, the Node.js project suffered a security incident relating to its CI/testing setup. They've now written up the details of whatÂ happened.

  • With Deno 2.3 just around the corner, the Deno team shares a few updates on recent improvements.

RELEASES:

  • â­ pnpm 10.9 â€“ The alternative, efficient packageÂ manager. It can now be used to install JSRÂ packages.

  • jsvu 3.0 â€“ Tool to install versions of various JavaScriptÂ engines.

  • SmallJS 1.6 â€“ A Smalltalk-80 implementation that runs inÂ JavaScript.

  • Bun v1.2.10, Node.js v22.15.0 (LTS), Next.js 15.4 Canary

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

Creating a 3D Split-Flap Display with JavaScript â€” A split-flap display is a electro-mechanical display commonly associated with live timetable displays and it makes for a neat effect on the Web too. Jhey breaks down how to replicate it, or you can hit up this liveÂ demo.

Jhey Tompkins

Impossible Components â€” Dan Abramov digs into the idea of so-called â€˜impossibleâ€™ components that mix server-only and client-only features and how React Server Components can help bridge the divide, culminating in an example you can experiment with forÂ yourself.

Dan Abramov

How to Build a Multi-Tenant App Using Clerk + Supabase â€” Clerk and Supabase empower you to build B2B apps with only a few small changes to your codebase. Learn how in thisÂ guide.

Clerk sponsor

Optimizing Node Performance with V8 GC Optimization â€” Matteo recently â–¶ï¸Â gave a talk about Nodeâ€™s memory usage and has written it up into this blog post. He notes that high memory usage doesnâ€™t necessarily mean you have a memory leak, explains how V8â€™s garbage collection works, and how to tune things for your own useÂ case.

Matteo Collina

Abusing DuckDB-WASM by Making SQL Draw 3D Graphics (Sort Of) â€” Oh, this is a fun experiment. DuckDB is a small and powerful in-process SQL database (think SQLite but for analytical tasks) and has a native WebAssembly build. Couple that with some JavaScript, and you too could do some rather bizarreÂ things..

Patrick Trainer

ğŸ’¡ Lest you think this is just a fun item, you could use the techniques learnt here to integrate DuckDB more seriously into other WebÂ projects.

ğŸ“„ A Decade of Impact: How Our npm Packages Hit 1 Billion Downloads and Shaped JavaScript â€“ A bold title for sure, but with a neat story behindÂ it. Forward Email

ğŸ“„ Float16Array in JavaScript â€“ Understanding the 16-bit floating point array type. Trevor I. Lasn

ğŸ“„ When to Use map() vs. forEach() Matt Smith

ğŸ“„ Zero-Config Debugging with Deno and OpenTelemetry Casonato and Jiang (Deno)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

JavaScript Font Picker â€” A surprisingly featureful control for letting users pick fonts from a range of system fonts, Google fonts, and custom fonts of your choice. You can play with a code demo here or go to the GitHubÂ repo.

Zygomatic

ğŸ¨ The folks behind this project have also built JS Color Picker.

Scala.js 1.19.0: A Way to Bring Scala and JavaScript Together â€” Scala is a powerful language that never quite seemed to make it big to me, but it has a devoted fanbase and has grown beyond its JVM roots to also have JavaScript and native runtimes. Scala.js is a Scala to JavaScript compiler and the homepage has some neat code and featureÂ comparisons.

Scala.js Team

Penpot Launches Native Design Tokens! â€” Simplify your design & code collaboration with Penpot design tokens: the key to consistency andÂ scalability.

Penpot sponsor

Spectacle: Create Sleek React-Powered Presentations â€” A React-based library for creating sleek presentations using JSX syntax that gives you the ability to live demo your code, add interactive elements, scrollable code blocks, graphics effects, andÂ more.

Nearform

Frimousse: A Lightweight, Unstyled, and Composable Emoji Picker forÂ React â€” The picker is accessible and wonâ€™t display any emojis that arenâ€™t supported on the device. You can explore some demosÂ here.

liveblocks

  • c15t (Consent Management) â€“ A React approach to transforming privacy consent from a mere checkbox into a fully observableÂ system.

  • bignumber.js 9.3 â€“ Arbitrary-precision decimal and non-decimalÂ arithmetic.

  • Milkdown 7.9 â€“ Plugin-driven WYSIWYG Markdown editorÂ framework.

  • Koota 0.4 â€“ Performant real-time ECS-based stateÂ management.

  • tablesort 5.6 â€“ Plain JS table row sortingÂ mechanism.

  • ğŸ“º React Lite YouTube Embed 2.5

  • ESLint v9.25.1

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

âœ‰ï¸ FYI: We publish two other JavaScript related newsletters if you work with Node.js or React: Node Weekly and React Status.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of other interesting updates and useful resources from across the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • ğŸ¤” The Microsoft Edge team is looking for feedback on a new console.context() method to enable "helpful contextual logging" within theÂ devtools.

  • ğŸ”­ David Cummings of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory gave a talk about â–¶ï¸Â how they diagnosed and fixed a problem on the Voyager 1 space probe while it was 15 billion miles away. If you ever think debugging a local app is difficult, this is nextÂ level.

  • ğŸ” The maximum lifetime of TLS certificates is set to be reduced to 47 days in a gradual process between early 2026 and 2029.

  • ğŸ¤¯ Google may be forced to sell Chrome, and guess who's interested in buyingÂ it?Â OpenAI, among others.

  • TIL you can interact with GitHub's GraphQL API with the GitHub CLI tool.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

åœ¨ç½‘ä¸Šé˜…è¯»

How to Build a Multi-Tenant App Using Clerk + Supabase â€” Clerk and Supabase empower you to build B2B apps with only a few smallæ›´æ”¹æ‚¨çš„ä»£ç åº“ã€‚ å­¦ä¹ å¦‚ä½•åœ¨æœ¬æŒ‡å—ä¸­ã€‚

åº—å‘˜

- æœ€è¿‘Matteo â–¶quate quate å¯¹Nodeçš„è®°å¿†è¿›è¡Œäº†è®¨è®ºï¼Œå¹¶å°†å…¶å†™å…¥äº†æœ¬åšå®¢æ–‡ç« ä¸­ã€‚ä»–æŒ‡å‡ºï¼Œé«˜å†…å­˜ä½¿ç”¨æƒ…å†µå¹¶ä¸ä¸€å®šæ„å‘³ç€æ‚¨æœ‰è®°å¿†æ³„æ¼ï¼Œè§£é‡Šäº†V8çš„åƒåœ¾æ”¶é›†çš„å·¥ä½œåŸç†ä»¥åŠå¦‚ä½•ä¸ºæ‚¨è‡ªå·±çš„ç”¨ä¾‹è°ƒæ•´å†…å®¹ã€‚

Matteo Collina

item.title: ã€Making V8 eager to compile your JavaScriptã€‘ä½¿V8æ¸´æœ›ç¼–è¯‘æ‚¨çš„JavaScript
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹734 â€” May 2, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

GSAP v3.13: JavaScript Animation Set Free â€” Last year the popular GSAP (a.k.a. GreenSock) animation library was acquired by Webflow and as of this new version the entire GSAP toolkit is freely available (including formerly paid addons like MorphSVG and SplitText) even for commercialÂ use. If you're unfamiliar with GSAP and want to see some of what it can do, they have a showcase, lots of codeÂ demos, and amazingÂ docs.

Cassie Evans and Jack Doyle

ğŸ’¡ Take care with the license though. GSAP is not formally 'open source' but has a â€˜no chargeâ€™ license that prevents you using it to directly compete with Webflow.

AG Charts: The Best JavaScript Charting Library in the World â€” Create beautiful JavaScript Charts in minutes with our open-source library. Built by AG Grid, AG Charts has an intuitive, flexible API, 20+ series types and advanced features, including Financial Charts. Supports React, Angular & Vue. Try forÂ free.

AG Charts sponsor

Converting Values to Strings in JavaScript â€” When Dr. Axel says â€œconverting values to strings in JavaScript is more complicated than it might seemâ€, Iâ€™m inclined to believe him. An interesting poke about into something seemingly simple you might not think about veryÂ much.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“‰Â Giving V8 a Heads-Up: Faster Startup with Explicit Compile Hints â€” A look at a V8 optimization that lets you direct V8 to eagerly compile specific files as a way to speed up startup. It ships with ChromeÂ 136 and the performance gains are more compelling than you mightÂ expect.

Marja HÃ¶lttÃ¤

IN BRIEF:

  • Node.js's releases are currently shifting around a little. v18 has just gone 'end of life', v23 has entered 'maintenance' mode and v24 is soon to land as the new 'current'Â release.

  • ğŸ¤  jQuery was first released in 2006 and to celebrate its 20th anniversary, there's a jQuery Reunion event in Texas on January 16-17,Â 2026.

  • The Svelte team has a look at what's new in Svelte lately, and the Astro team has a similar update for Astro too.

  • You can now install JSR packages with pnpm and Yarn.

  • Learn about JavaScript's numerous operators with a handy online reference.

RELEASES:

  • Deno 2.3 â€“ The alternative JavaScript runtime improves its single binary compilation feature to support FFI and Node nativeÂ addons.

  • Prisma 6.7 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js andÂ TypeScript.

  • Bun v1.2.11, Electron 36, pnpm 10.10

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

Export Google Analytics Data to Google Sheets via Apps Script â€” Google Apps Script is a JavaScript-based platform for dynamically automating tasks in all sorts of Google apps. Hereâ€™s how to use it to bring Google Analytics data into a GoogleÂ Sheet.

Kayce Basques

Building an Offline-Friendly Image Upload System â€” How to leverage PWA tech such as IndexedDB, service workers, and the Background Sync API to help improve the reliability of web apps for users, particularly those with unreliable internetÂ connectivity.

Amejimaobari Ollornwi

How to Take Clerk to Production â€” How to take a Clerk app to production with custom domains, OAuth credentials, and DNSÂ setup.

Clerk sponsor

What Does React's 'use client' Do? â€” Dan Abramov takes a practical look at how to think about the use client and use server directives React Server Components introduced and how they let you elegantly structure a client/server app as â€œa single program spanning two environmentsâ€ â€“ a concept that Dan thinks could be more widely used, even outside ofÂ React.

Dan Abramov

ğŸ“„ Denoâ€™s Decline? â€“ A critical view of Denoâ€™s Deno Deploy edge platform which has been steadily droppingÂ regions. David Bushell

ğŸ“º How to Detect Memory Leaks in Your Web App Decoded Frontend

ğŸ“„ Pwning the Ladybird Browser â€“ The vector is Ladybirdâ€™s LibJS JavaScriptÂ engine. Jess

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

PDFSlick 3.0: View and Interact with PDF Documents in JS Apps â€” A full-featured PDF viewer for React, Solid, Svelte and vanilla JS apps. Built on top of PDF.js, it offers a wide array of features from simple PDF viewing to working with multiple and large documents with annotations. Demo. v3.0 bumps up to PDF.js v5 with ICC profile support, better JPEG 2000 support, and improved rendering of largeÂ pages.

Vancho Stojkov

Koa 3.0: The Expressive HTTP Middleware Framework â€” Koa first appeared a decade ago as a â€˜next-generationâ€™ Web framework that shared some of the lineage of Express.js, but leaning on more modern JS features. While Express has been making a comeback, Koa remains a compellingÂ alternative.

Koa contributors

Your Terminal, Evolved â€” The new agentic CLI from AWS works with you to write files locally, run bash commands, or call AWS APIs. Start forÂ free!

Amazon sponsor

Seyfert: A Framework for Building Discord Bots â€” Create bots for the popular chat system starting from bots that respond to simple commands up to creating components and getting user input. Supports Deno, Bun, and Node.

socram03

Storybook 9 Beta â€” A strong step forward for the UI â€˜frontend workshopâ€™ with several experimental features from Storybook 8 becoming stable. v9 has a strong focus on component testing, plus React NativeÂ support.

Michael Shilman

PGlite 0.3: Postgres but in WebAssembly â€” A WebAssembly-based build of the Postgres SQL database meaning you can run it wherever WebAssembly can be run (such as in the browser as in thisÂ demo).

ElectricSQL

  • pretty-bytes 7.0 â€“ Convert a size in bytes into a human readableÂ equivalent (e.g. 1337 â†’ 1.34Â kB).

  • QuickJS 2.2 â€“ Execute JavaScript code in a WebAssembly QuickJSÂ sandbox.

  • Piscina 5.0 â€“ Popular Node.js worker threadÂ pool.

  • Jira.js 5.0 â€“ A wrapper for Jira's numerousÂ APIs.

  • NodeBB 4.3 â€“ Node.js-powered forumÂ system.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of other interesting updates and useful resources from across the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • Redis is open source again! The popular Redis in-memory data store ran into a bit of drama in recent years with a license change following its acquisition. The good news is that an AGPL license is now an option for the new Redis 8 release making Redis truly 'open source again.'

  • TypeScript â†â†’ C#: I've been dabbling with a little C# recently (it's the main language used in Unity game development) and enjoyed this TypeScript is Like C# guide oriented largely around showing TypeScript/JavaScript vs C# examples of doing the sameÂ things.

  • â¤ï¸ JS + HTML: It's a simple thing, but Simon Willison reminds us that static HTML enriched with JavaScript and served up on GitHub Pages is one of the best ways you can give software freely for the world to use.

  • Emulators-a-plenty: Tiny Emus is a showcase of almost 200 emulators that run in the browser, largely for 8 bit platforms, games, and even some visual CPUÂ demos.

  • CSS shapes: Did you know CSS now has a shape() function for drawing complex shapes for clipping paths?
